Likes and Dislikes
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher Advance Archive (GameBoy Advance): Ranching Tips: Likes and Dislikes
By Draco the Sage on Saturday, January 5, 2002 - 05:58 am:

Ok. 1: Why hasn't anyone talked about this? 2: Is it all that important? For example, I had a Dogmar that Liked Sleeping, and Disliked Ace(My name). If it Dislikes me, does it really matter? All I noticed was a slight increase in power, but slight decrease in defense , and a liitle more stress. I chalked it up to taking its rage out in the battle. I had a Sp. Lesione (not Irassie, can't remember its name) who Liked Playing and Disliked Battle. How do you Play? I think that the Dislike of battle means it gets more stress or less defense. Could someone just answer my question?

By xenon_atom on Saturday, January 5, 2002 - 09:51 am:

don't think it matters at all, maybe just a bit. I had one(Diamante) that liked playing, disliked battle, too. It worked just fine in battle, wasn't stressed, good stats, etc. Got to A class, but then I decided to use a different monster instead.
Also, my Nut Arrow which liked battle, disliked playing, ended up the same. Not higher defence/less stress or anything.

By Lisa Shock on Saturday, January 5, 2002 - 01:46 pm:

In other MR games, the like/dislikes affected stress & fatigue generated by actives, and reduced by food. Liked foods, for example, reduced more stress & fatigue than if the exact same food was disliked. If battles were disliked, more fatigue would develop, if liked, less fatigue was the result. It's usually not a huge difference, but a rancher may need to be aware of the preferences, and expect to slightly alter their raising method accordingly.

By Draco the Sage on Saturday, January 5, 2002 - 06:47 pm:

Thanks for your help, but no one addressed my OTHER question. How do you PLAY with your monsters? Is that training? Or is that something differant, nonexistant or hidden? I'd really like to know.

By Lisa Shock on Saturday, January 5, 2002 - 07:14 pm:

Does not appear to exist in this game, there were min-games in MR2 where you could. Essentially, it meant that if a monster got to being spoiled, they would want to waste weeks playing instead of drilling. If you gave in you lost valuable weeks of statgains just to play. Now, I think it means they will get spoiled faster, and tend to fail more on drills they aren't good at.

By xenon_atom on Sunday, January 6, 2002 - 10:14 am:

My monster which liked playing/disliked battles did just fine in drills, and succeeded all the time, so I'm not sure about that. I think that playing just isn't in the game, and it just tells you that you have a playful monster for pretty much no reason

By ali unico on Thursday, January 10, 2002 - 01:15 pm:

in a way i kinda like not having to play..when i would be working on training it ...it seemed to always want to play..i didnt want to tell it no but sometimes i had to..now i dont have to worry

most of my monsters likes present and dislikes nothing...
